title: How to survive without high school diploma - Quora

response.answer_text: It isn’t easy. Many jobs that pay anything require at least a HS diploma or equivalent before they’ll even consider you (no matter what other qualifications you have). Getting other qualifications will be hard since most community college programs (even career track diplomas) and vocational schools require a high school diploma or equivalent. Today, you can’t even join the military without a HS diploma or equivalent (and I think it may only be the Army now that will consider you if you have a HS equivalent, i.e. a GED, instead of an actual HS diploma). So, what can you do? You have a few options. Get your GED. That will open a lot of other options. I knew someone in high school who dropped out, got her GED, went to a Community College, then joined the military, and eventually became an officer (she went to the service academy for the service she joined after her 4 years of active duty were up) and now has 2 masters degrees (and I think she is about to start her third). From the GED, you can get any HS grad job (most of which don’t pay well without a skill), you can go to vocational school to get a skill if you don’t want to go to college (some job skills pay very well), you can go to a 2 year college and get your associates degree (some AA/AS level skills pay quite well), you can join the military or you can even go on to college and get a 4-year degree or beyond. Start your own business. If you have a skill that is useful this is a possibility. Depending upon what you want to do, you may have to find a way to raise a substantial amount of money, and there is definitely risk to this route, so it is not for everyone. If you are lucky enough to land a good sales job (not retail) without a HS diploma, sales is a skill that doesn’t necessarily require much formal education. If you can develop the skills, one can make a lot of money in sales without college. If you are under 21 and can finish HS before you are 21, consider going back. It may not be fun to be 21 in class with 14–18 year old students, and it may be hard to convince a school to let you in. It may be easier if your local school district offers evening school since those students will mostly be on the older side of high school students. This way you can get your actual HS diploma which will open more doors than a GED (and far more than nothing). Many students who struggled in day school find evening school works better for them.

As a high school dropout who now has his teaching degree and teachers 11–14 year olds for a living, i think i am well suited to answer this question. you wont even survive if you dont have some grit and tenacity, no matter what, that diploma was a missed goal, but MOVE ONDo you have any real world skills already? this will allow you to get by, but only just.Work on bettering yourself or your skill: if you answered yes to #2, and its a serviceable skill, keep at it, get better at it, refine it, and make money from it. If you find that your skill isnt getting it done, time for the next stepGED. This was my route. got mine while i was in jail at age 18. best 4 hours i ever spent taking that test. Note: the GED is written at a tenth grade level, if you were a successful student to that point, dont bother with the whole extended study session, take the test. you can always try it again.Get passionate! Whether you have a PhD or no education at all, if you have a deep passion and love for what you do, you will tend to (TEND TO) be successful, not just surviving. Now success to some is borderline poverty to others, but the tempered American dream still lives.Choices, you have got to make some really good ones and SOON, or things will not be looking good. Start with a small one today, can you enroll in (or take) a GED Exam ASAP? if not, ask yourself why and what the other option is today. From #4 to #5 above i went to community college, got my AA. spent a few more years in limbo until #5 took hold, then went back to school to get my teaching degree. Satisfied for now, but raises are based on credentials, so its a Masters degree sometime soon too. and on it goes…

I wish I had more information about your situation, so I could give you a better answer. Where I live, once you are considered a mature student, you can get credit toward your diploma for work experience, and will only need 4 actual high school classes to get your diploma. Is it possible your city offers a similar arrangement? What about night school, online courses, or correspondence courses? Are any of those possible? Some colleges will accept students who do not have high school diplomas if they can pass an admissions or equivalency test. If school is out of the question, try and find a job that has the possibility for promotion by hard work. You might have to start at the bottom, but if you show you have talent and are willing to work hard, you will be promoted. Have you thought about apprenticeship? Again, if I knew more about you, I could give you better advice. Some trades do not require a high school diploma, and you earn your qualifications (and get paid) as you learn your trade. Is there a small business you could start on your own? Do you have a special skill that you could turn into a job? Whatever you end up doing, remember that there is always dignity in honest labour. Good luck to you!

It’s going to take effort. The hard part is, you are young and—no matter what you may want to believe—you are not used to thinking long term. If you can make yourself think long term, your chances of “survival” increase dramatically. To think long terms means: To not get too committed to anyone’s big ideas (of what’s/who’s cool, or of politics, or of what’s right/wrong).To have diverse groups of friends, and be ok with the different groups staying separated. Just don’t get caught up in conflicts between the various groups. And don’t let yourself be forced to choose sides—there are always more friends somewhere.Stay away from risk-takers. You’ll have plenty of time for that in adult life, if you don’t limit your options early.Get good grades. Keep your options open.I don’t know what your definition of “surviving” high school is, but I recommend that your goal be to get through it without burning any bridges to success in life, because nothing in high school is worth that. Hope that helps! All the best…

Learn a skill that someone will pay you to perform. That might mean working for someone, it might mean freelancing. The computer repair guy I go to has no diploma…he’s just a whiz at fixing stuff. And I hired a contractor with no high school diploma once who started out in lowly house construction and worked his way up to owning his own business. it’s doable..but it’s hard. The trick is to come up with a skill that makes you valuable, then become very good at it. If you speak a second language, you can probably find work as a translator, or work in a field where that language is used a lot. Definitely get the GED, it will open so many more doors.

I wasn't going to answer this question because at first I didn't know how to.  Angel, that's terrible advice!  Finishing high school is important if you're going to college. If you're not, it's not important.  Find something that you want to do, and don't allow anyone to tell you that you can't do it.  Read books on the subject, listen to Ted talks, watch how-to videos on YouTube; become the person who you want to be. Research.  Dont get too caught up on a piece of paper.  It's like marriage, the paper doesn't legitimize the relationship, the parties do.  "The only thing between you and your goals are your actions." -Someone

Greetings, In 2020, individuals who did not finish high schools must possess valuable workplace skills to prosper. Please keep in mind that high school drop-outs are not necessarily illiterate or bereft of math skills. There are a number of tradespeople who do not have a high school diploma. In my area, family businesses employ individuals who have not completed high school, but every one of those workers have distinguished themselves as capable journeymen in their walk of life. Sincerely, AJG.

Easy-don’t let the academic work take a “back seat.” Join clubs, join a sports team, and go to events like balls, proms, and formals. But remember that the work comes FIRST. You will not get a diploma after four years for just playing football, being on the cheer squad, or taking a cute girl to the prom. I graduated seventh in my high school class back in 1995 and that opened up a lot of options for me.
You will find a blue collar job with much physical demands and low pay. You might need two. You might not improve your economica situacion but you will "survive". Good luck!
